captions.text:
Men, normally with this information it
would take time to make a more intricate plan of attack.

however, rather than transmitting the
technical readouts of the Imperial Battle Station...

and keeping our hidden base safe,
Princess Leia insisted on coming back

knowing full well her ship was being
tracked.
In short, we have one chance to make this right and it's all Princess Leia's fault.
Sir, we have reached the planet Yemen.
the rebel base is on a moon orbiting on the other side of the planet.
We will be in firing range within 30 minutes
I say we're in range now.
The death star is in range. The death star is in range.
Well, so much for that idea.
I was this close to going back and helping those people.
Let him beat you, you had to.
What will I do now, tell me? Hmmm?!

comments.author: Vincent Morreale

comments.text:
I like this HiSHE episode, pretty damn funny. 
Imagine the chaos in the immediate area of the planet after it gets blown 
up. How much matter is there exploding outwards. 
1) The death star probably wouldn't be able to get a clean shot on the moon 
because of all that exploding matter.
2) They probably wouldn't need a clean shot, the exploding matter from the 
planet would likely wipe out anything on the moon surface. 
3) And I dunno, maybe the moon itself might have been broken up? Dunno.

But ultimately, The Rule of Cool trumps all other rules. 

Because if you don't follow The Rule of Cool you'd be asking all kinds of 
questions.

1) What powers the Death Star?
2) If it's the size of a moon, how does it even travel between star systems 
in a reasonable time?
3) How do they get the fuel the DS needs if it travels as fast as other 
ships and needs to strike undetected?
4) Why do they need a DS? They could have built thousands if not millions 
of other ships for the cost of the DS!

Yes, you could pose questions ad nauseam, but ultimately the questions 
don't matter. Rule of Cool. If it works, it works. And based on the success 
of the franchise there's no way to argue that Star Wars didn't work.﻿
comments.author: azangor

comments.text:
+azangor There's an answer to #4: Intimidation of potentially rebellious 
planets. ("Fear will keep them in line... fear of this battle station.") 
And the scary part about the Death Star's superlaser wasn't necessarily its 
ability to wipe out a planet completely, but its ability to penetrate 
planetary defense shields that could deflect turbolaser bombardments by 
normal ships.

comments.author: Nathan T (hppavilion1)

comments.text:
I've been reading people saying that the Death Star needed to charge before 
making another shot.  Does anyone have official proof of how long it would 
have had to charge for how powerful of a shot?

I've read someone say it takes 24 hours for a fully powered shot.  But, 
sense Yavin was a gas giant, would it have really needed a fully powered 
shot to destroy its core?  What if Yavin only required a half powered shot 
and the other half could have been used on the moon?  How big was the 
moon?  Could it be destroyed with 1/10th of a fully charged shot?

We would need to know how long it takes the Death Star to fully charge, and 
how much of that charge it would take to destroy the two bodies.  
Otherwise, we're all just shooting into the dark with random ass theories.  
It just seems to me that the center of a gas giant and a moon, even back to 
back,  wouldn't even take a fully charged shot to destroy; as a solid large 
planet would.  But, again, without the above information, I'm just guessing.

Also, none of this matters.  The fact of the matter is that destroying the 
base would have done absolutely nothing to spare the Death Star after the 
X-Wing Launch.  Luke used the Force to time his shot, so there was no need 
for targeting input or radio chatter.  Most people besides Luke and Han 
just seemed to serve the purpose of dying so we could see ships blow up and 
create tension.  But did any of the X-Wings need the base to communicate, 
or can then communicate between themselves?

Granted, there would be no base to fly back to; couldn't Han just dock the 
X-Wing to the Falcon and bring Luke in?

Hehehehe......  :-)﻿
comments.author: shaalazin

comments.text:
The idea of say, exploding a planet is physically speaking, give every 
atoms of that planet enough energy to escape their gravitation attraction 
to themselves. Gas giants are actually very big, very heavy and have very 
strong gravitational field. And it's not as if they are full of gas only. 
at lower altitudes, the gravitation is so great that gas condense to liquid 
(I'm describing Jupiter). So if anything, you will need more energy to blow 
it up. Or just shoot straight through it.

But if you can explode the gas giant, the moon will be doomed. Flying 
debris from the exploding giant would have burned and stripped the moon of 
its atmosphere; scorching and killing everyone on the moon's surface. Any 
flying X-wings would like be a) incinerated by the debris, b) shot down.

At that point, the Death Star only need to send a transmission: "Surrender 
now, you have no where to go back to. It's crap to be a prisoner but that 
sure beats being frozen to death in this lonely galaxy".

comments.author: Sean Jau (SupermarineSJ)

comments.text:
+Neg Ative , +brian head  basically summed up my point. Yavin IV has its 
own gravity. While there will certainly be some disruption caused by the 
loss of Yavin's gravity, (rapid changes to tides, possibly earthquakes and 
changed volcanic activity, depends on how close it was.) And as brian 
points out, quite possibly impacts from Yavin's debris, (Though we'd need 
some more data on the size of Yavin, and the distance of Yavin IV to make 
some estimates of how much would actually hit.. )

Personally, I also doubt that the first death star had the power to blow 
apart a big planet like Yavin effectively. It was a lot more massive than a 
standard inhabitable planet, and may have had enough gravity to pull itself 
back together after being blasted apart.
I'm sure someone could take data from the movies and Wookiepedia, do some 
analysis if they really wanted.
comments.author: Thomas Walder

comments.text:
WOW physics of Ep IV...really? i hope none of you went to Cal tech for your 
physics...1. Gravity is NOT the issue...If Yavin explodes, it will slam 
into Yavin 4...there is no guarantee to the size of particles...but we must 
assume there are going to be large peices...if they have any body of 
waters, then there will be a tidle wave. if not, depending on the location 
of the base, under ground or not, there will be small impact 
quakes....remember that an impact of an asteroid will have an  affected 
radius of damage, if the base is NO WHERE nearby, then it does not 
matter...a  quake is from the fault lines and tectonic plates...an impact 
from a body of mass,, depending on the size and location of the Rebel Base, 
is insignificant...

As you know, the moon's mass provides its own gravity, despite the change 
in its orbital trajectory...it will still have atmosphere, because of its 
liquid hot core...The Death Star takes time to recharge, as well.
comments.author: brian head

comments.text:
+Thomas Walder 
Wait, so in your opinion the sudden loss of Yavin wouldn't cause a massive 
disruption to Yavin IV's orbit and gravity resulting in everything not 
nailed down to be flung off, however temporarily, into the system? Sure the 
star's gravity would probably grab Yavin IV and everything that used to be 
held to it by its gravity and establish a new orbit for it around the star 
but in the interim everything alive on the moon would be violently killed 
due to exposure to vacuum and loss of atmosphere if they were lucky enough 
not to be pulverized by the massive quantities of collisions that resulted 
from it. I would suspect the end result would be a new planet (formerly the 
moon Yavin IV) and a new ring of debris similar in appearance to one of 
Sol's asteroid belts littered with rebel bodies and wreckage of what was 
left of their fleet.
Not trying to be argumentative or rude but I do find this to be the most 
likely scenario and I would love to see a CG depiction of this event! Could 
you provide more insight as to why your scenario seems more plausible to 
you and describe the end result of it as I did mine? Both theories I find 
very interesting and I'd like to hear more about yours please.
comments.author: Neg Ative

comments.text:
Too slow-  destroying Yavin would trigger earthquakes in Yavin VI, but

from a few hours to several days (I don't know VI's orbital parameters) and 
even then, it would just be moving into orbit around the parent star.

comments.author: rollercoaster478

comments.text:
Gas giants have solid cores, they are essentially tiny planets with 
massive, gassy atmospheres. The core ensures there is enough gravity to 
hold the gasses in place, otherwise the field of gas would just disperse 
into space. With a solid core, the DS could just fire at Yavin's center and 
wipe the whole thing out.

As mentioned this would also screw over the moon as the gravitational pull 
keeping it in orbit around Yavin would be gone, they would likely be 
showered in debris from Yavin's core etc.

That, or they could simply have held position, waited for the moon to do a 
rotation and get into range, all the while blocking the moon with a fleet.

Or hell, just send in a fleet and bombard the base into oblivion. I really 
don't see why they did not just do that, it's not like they lack in Star 
Destroyers...

comments.author: DaLatinKnight

comments.text:
+Me Myself and I....Gas giants aren't really habitable and are way way more 
massive. To say that a system simply can destroy anything we define as a 
planet is  well stupid. Planets have a large range of properties, the death 
star clearly had to be at least close to 100% charged to destroy a rock 
planet like Alderaan. That means it doesn't have the juice to destroy a gas 
giant.
comments.author: arhalts

comments.text:
+arhalts
What is a planet destroyer if it can't destroy a planet? c'mon.
comments.author: Me Myself and I

comments.text:
+idunbeezasmart1... did you not read what I wrote. ..... The death star 
probably couldn't blow up that planet. If it could it could have blown up a 
rocky planet the size of earth at 1% charge.  A gas giant has a ton of mass 
and a ton of gravity. This means you have to pump in way more energy to 
heat the planet the same amount and you have to reach a much higher heat 
level to blow it up.

If the death star shot a gas giant, in all likely hood the gas giant would 
shrug, say meh and carry on in it's obit completely unaffected.
comments.author: arhalts

comments.text:
+arhalts Except it was a moon the rebel base was on. Therefore, the gas 
giant had to have had more mass in order to keep the moon in orbit. Even if 
there wasn't a lot of debris, the immediate loss of gravitational pull and 
even some debris would've obliterated any living being on the moon's 
surface. While the moon itself might not be destroyed, the rebels certainly 
would've.
comments.author: idunbeezasmart1

comments.text:
Like this ending, not a fan of star wars really, but the energy difference 
between blowing up a rocky planet comparable to earth and blowing up a gas 
giant is enormous
comments.author: arhalts

comments.author: Steven Daniels

comments.author: TheGiftedGuy

comments.text:
I don't understand some of these comments. We see the deathstar deploying 
tie fighters in the movie. If they wanted to they could have deployed 
enough to stop any escape from Yavin 4 by the small rebel band. If the 
deathstar didn't have the ability to launch near unlimited amounts it was a 
waste of opportunity and space. Any battlestation that large should act 
secondarily as a mothership to be able to protect itself in a battle as it 
becomes a target. Tarkin I can imagine would have made sure it had whatever 
force was necessary to stop anything, even an entire planetary fleet, maybe 
more. Your planet destroyer isn't much good if a planets ships can blow it 
up before you destroy the planet.﻿
comments.author: Luigi84289
